title: Don Yule
text:
Don Yule (January 28, 1935, <a href="Enid%2C%20Oklahoma">Enid, Oklahoma</a> — July 3, 2015, <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>) was an American <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="bass%20%28voice%20type%29">bass</a> who performed regularly with the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a> (NYCO) for fifty years. A graduate of the <a href="Jacobs%20School%20of%20Music">Jacobs School of Music</a> at <a href="Indiana%20University">Indiana University</a>, he joined the NYCO in 1960 where he made his debut as Gluttony in a revival of <a href="Hugo%20Weisgall">Hugo Weisgall</a>’s "<a href="Six%20Characters%20in%20Search%20of%20an%20Author%20%28opera%29">Six Characters in Search of an Author</a>". He went on to perform in a total of 83 roles with the NYCO in more than 1,700 performances, most often in <a href="comprimario">comprimario</a> parts. Some of the roles he was associated with included Alcindoro and Benoit in <a href="Giacomo%20Puccini">Giacomo Puccini</a>'s "<a href="La%20Boh%C3%A8me">La Bohème</a>", Antonio and Bartolo in Mozart's "<a href="The%20Marriage%20of%20Figaro">The Marriage of Figaro</a>", Dr. Grenvil in <a href="Giuseppe%20Verdi">Giuseppe Verdi</a>'s "<a href="La%20Traviata">La Traviata</a>", and the Jailer and the Sacristan in Puccini's "<a href="Tosca">Tosca</a>". 
Yule notably created the role of Professor Grippel in the world premiere of <a href="Gian%20Carlo%20Menotti">Gian Carlo Menotti</a>'s "<a href="The%20Most%20Important%20Man">The Most Important Man</a>" in 1971. In 1982 he portrayed the Huntsman and the Bulgarian Soldier in <a href="Hal%20Prince">Hal Prince</a>'s celebrated revival of <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a>'s "<a href="Candide%20%28operetta%29">Candide</a>" which was filmed for national broadcast on <a href="PBS">PBS</a>'s "<a href="Live%20from%20Lincoln%20Center">Live from Lincoln Center</a>". He later performed the roles of the First Inquisitioner, Don, and Judge on the NYCO's recording of the work which won the <a href="Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Opera%20Recording">Grammy Award for Best Opera Recording</a> in 1987. His final performance with the NYCO was in 2010. He died at his home in Brooklyn in 2015 at the age of 80.
